feed.title: Combined summary - RBF Pinning with Counterparties and Competing Interest

entry.title: Combined summary - RBF Pinning with Counterparties and Competing Interest
entry.summary: The Lightning Network developer community has been discussing potential vulnerabilities of the network, including low-fee-rate transactions being difficult to evict from the Bitcoin mempool, creating a potential vulnerability for denial-of-service attacks. One proposed solution is to limit the size of low-fee-rate transaction packages within the mempool. Another suggestion involves allowing transactors to mark their transactions as "likely-to-be-RBF'ed", enabling a relay policy where children of such transactions would be rejected unless the resulting package would be "near the top of the mempool". In addition, the discussion includes proposals for protecting against malicious participants broadcasting low-fee HTLC-success or Remote-HTLC-success transactions and ways to address pinning attacks. There are also concerns over incentivizing LN nodes to connect to high hashrate pools and the use of pay-for-signature construction in pointlocked timelock contracts (PTLCs).In recent discussions on the Lightning-dev mailing list, several vulnerabilities in Bitcoin's lightning protocol were raised. One vulnerability involves a bidding war between the counterparty and the original party over HTLC value. Another vulnerability discussed involves an attack that could be launched by a counterparty on the Lightning Network involving spending an HTLC using the preimage with a low-fee, RBF-disabled transaction and then getting the HTLC-claiming transaction mined via some out-of-band agreement with a small miner, leaving the original party short the HTLC value. The email also discusses modifications to the state machine for lightning implementations and potential solutions to issues with HTLC output spends. On April 22, 2020, Olaoluwa Osuntokun and Matt Corallo discussed potential solutions to address issues related to Bitcoin contracts. The conversation centered on the limitations of package limits in Bitcoin contracts, with Osuntokun questioning the need for such limitations in more complex contracts while Corallo defended them as anti-DoS measures. The discussion also touched on monitoring the global mempool for safe execution of transactions.The Bitcoin-dev mailing list has seen discussions on several issues related to the security of the Bitcoin network. One issue is mempool-pinning, a type of attack where a malicious party delays an honest party's transaction in the mempool by sticking their own transactions there. Solutions proposed include resuscitating old work and deploying package relay. Another issue discussed is RBF pinning HTLC transactions in the lightning protocol, which can result in theft of funds. Solutions include adding an RBF carve-out output to HTLC-Timeout or using SIGHASH_NOINPUT for C-side signature. The Lightning Network, a second-layer solution built on top of the Bitcoin blockchain to enable faster and cheaper transactions, has identified a flaw in its update mechanics that allows users to steal in-flight HTLCs enforced on-chain using RBF Pinning. To resolve this issue, the Lightning Network came up with an idea called "anchor outputs," which allows both counterparties to add fees to a transaction being broadcast without getting into the quagmire that is RBF pinning. However, this trick comes with a narrow structure rule. A potential solution to incentivize miners for knowledge is by using a confirmed P2WPKH UTXO and spending part of its value on a scriptPubKey with OP_SHA256 OP_EQUAL, according to Matt. The bribe can be created via LN and sent as probes that reuse earlier HTLCs, allowing non-miners to profit from learning the preimage from miners. However, ZmnSCPxj noted that pay-to-preimage doesn't work with PTLCs and suggested advocating for making pay-to-revealed-adaptor-signature possible using something like OP_CHECKSIGFROMSTACK, which implies A[p4s] = a[p4s] * G is a one-time-use keypair. While this solution may be useful, it requires people to run additional software to keep track of potential preimages and then compare them to hash candidates and also requires additional complexity in LN clients. Overall, the email thread provides a detailed discussion of various potential attacks on Lightning Network channels and proposes solutions to mitigate them. It also includes links to the bitcoin-dev mailing list and its subscription page.
